title: Tables
text:
Relational databases store data in two-dimensional tables representing one object or entity about which we collect and store data.

Each column identifies an attribute of the object or entity the table describes.
Each row identifies an instance of a unique entity or object the table describes.

title: SQL Scripts
text: aslandj wl;kj adv. ax qweor ijasdf.

title: Relationships
text:
One-to-One, One-to-Many (most common and is the case on this page), or Many-to-Many



Figure 2: CustID, the primary key in the Customer table, and CustID, the foreign key in the Sales Order table form a relationship between the tables.

title: Key Attributes
text: A primary key is one or more columns in a table that uniquely identifies individual rows. The primary key column(s) must contain values (i.e., they cannot be NULL). A foreign key is a column that is a primary key in another table that is used to link two tables together.

title: Normalization
text: The goal is to avoid update anomalies, insert anomalies, and delete anomalies.

title: Normalization
text:
Update Anomalies
Customer address change requires updates to every occurrence of the customer address.



Figure 4:

title: Normalization
text:
Insert Anomalies
New customers will not be added until they place an order, or they will be added with null values.



Figure 5:

title: Normalization
text:
Delete Anomalies
Deleting an order for a customer with only one purchase will result in the deletion of all customer information.
